overview.title: What are Uncountable Nouns?
overview.description: [translate: Uncountable nouns refer to substances, concepts, or masses that cannot be counted individually.] They do not have plural forms and often represent abstract ideas or mass objects.
key_points: Often represent substances, qualities, or concepts
overview.importance: Understanding uncountable nouns is essential for correctly expressing quantities and making grammatically correct sentences.

sections.title: Definition and Characteristics
sections.content: [translate: Uncountable nouns describe things that can't be counted as separate units.] They often represent substances, liquids, qualities, or abstract ideas.

subsections.subtitle: Mass and Abstract Concepts
subsections.text: Examples include 'water' (a liquid), 'rice' (a mass), 'information' (a concept), and 'advice' (an intangible).

sections.title: Grammar and Usage
sections.content: Uncountable nouns cannot be used with numbers and do not have plural forms. They are paired with quantifiers like 'some', 'much', or 'a little' to express amount.

subsections.subtitle: Using Quantifiers
subsections.text: 'Some water', 'much information', 'a little rice'. Use 'many' or numbers only with countable items.

subsections.subtitle: Expressions for Quantity
subsections.text: For specific amounts, use units related to the noun (e.g., 'a glass of water', 'two pieces of advice').

sections.title: Common Uncountable Nouns
sections.content: Uncountable nouns often include liquids, foods, substances, qualities, and abstract ideas.

subsections.subtitle: Categories
subsections.text: Liquids (water, milk), foods (rice, sugar), substances (sand, hair), qualities (honesty, courage), abstract ideas (information, advice).

grammar_rules.title: Do not use plural forms with uncountable nouns
grammar_rules.description: Uncountable nouns remain singular and do not take -s endings.

grammar_rules.title: Use quantifiers like 'some', 'much', and 'a little'
grammar_rules.description: Since uncountable nouns can't be counted, use quantifiers to express amounts.

grammar_rules.title: Use measure words to specify quantity
grammar_rules.description: Use units or containers to count uncountable nouns (e.g., 'a cup of tea').
grammar_rules.tip: Add units to quantify uncountable nouns.

grammar_rules.title: Uncountable nouns take singular verbs
grammar_rules.description: Treat uncountable nouns as singular subjects in sentences.

grammar_rules.title: Some nouns can be both countable and uncountable
grammar_rules.description: Context determines if a noun is countable or uncountable (e.g., 'chicken' as animal or meat).

examples.analysis: 'Water' is an uncountable noun referring to a liquid.

examples.sentence: She added some sugar to the tea.
Rice is a staple food in many countries.
She ate some bread for breakfast.
He poured some juice into the glass.
Furniture needs to be dusted regularly.
examples.analysis: 'Furniture' is an uncountable noun for items.

examples.sentence: Traffic is heavy during rush hour.
She gained a lot of experience.

complex_sentences.sentence: She drank a glass of water after her run.
complex_sentences.analysis: 'Water' is uncountable; 'glass' is used to measure quantity.

complex_sentences.sentence: Information provided by the team was helpful.
Many people appreciate good advice during tough times.
complex_sentences.analysis: 'Advice' is uncountable, but can be pluralized in certain contexts.

common_mistakes.explanation: Uncountable nouns do not have plural forms.
common_mistakes.tip: Use 'much' or 'some' instead of numbers for uncountable nouns.

common_mistakes.explanation: Use 'some' or no article with uncountable nouns, not 'a' or 'an'.
common_mistakes.tip: Avoid indefinite articles before uncountable nouns.

common_mistakes.error_type: Using countable quantifiers with uncountable nouns
common_mistakes.wrong: Much apples are on the table.
common_mistakes.correct: Many apples are on the table.
common_mistakes.explanation: 'Much' is for uncountable nouns, 'many' for countable nouns.
common_mistakes.tip: Use quantifiers that match the noun type.

common_mistakes.correct: I bought two bottles of water.
common_mistakes.explanation: Use measure words for quantities of uncountable nouns.
common_mistakes.tip: Specify units when counting uncountable nouns.

common_mistakes.error_type: Confusing uncountable nouns with plural countables

common_mistakes.tip: Use singular verb forms with uncountable nouns.

common_mistakes.explanation: Use singular form for uncountable abstract nouns.
